claims: The paper provides an in-depth analysis of H-1B and F1 visa data.
A comprehensive dataset of 116,000 records and over 150 features was used for the analysis.
Data pre-processing, feature engineering, and sampling techniques were employed to handle data imbalance and improve model performance.
The Random Forest Classifier was explored under various configurations and sampling approaches to deal with the large imbalance between 'certified' and 'denied' visa statuses.
Synthetic balancing using SMOTE significantly improved the model's ability to accurately predict outcomes.

numbers.context: number of records in the dataset
number of features in the dataset

claims: Fuzzy string matching was used to deal with variations in spellings and characters.
The 'EMPLOYER_STATE' feature had variations in spellings and characters, such as 'California', 'CALIFORNIA', and 'California [PAGE 3] 34523'.
A list of all US states was created and used against all values in the 'EMPLOYER_STATE' feature to match using fuzzy string matching.
The 'MAJOR_MATCH' feature was engineered using two features: 'MAJOR_FIELD_OF_STUDY' and 'FOREIGN_WORKER_INFO_MAJOR'.
Fuzzy string matching with a similarity threshold of 80% was used for the 'MAJOR_MATCH' feature.
One-hot encoding was applied to the 'EMPLOYER_STATE' feature.
The 'COUNTRY_OF_CITIZENSHIP' feature was also one-hot encoded due to its importance in visa applications.
The 'CASE_STATUS' feature had 4 distinct classes: Certified, Certified - Expired, Withdrawn, and Denied.

numbers.context: number of records with Certified status
number of records with Certified - Expired status
number of records with Withdrawn status
number of records with Denied status

claims: The classifier was highly biased towards the majority class in experiments 1 and 2.
Using SMOTE to augment new data for the minority class improved performance metric values.
Down-sampling the majority class improved the classifier's ability to identify instances from the negative class.
Balancing the dataset by sampling the same number of instances from both classes resulted in better performance.
Synthetic oversampling for the minority class achieved the best results in experiment 8.
